formalMetadata.description: A document with text in English that contains nautical terms. The head element contains a link element that references a glossary where these terms are explained. Some user agents uses this this link element to generate an additional (navigation) bar that enables the user to access the glossary.
formalMetadata.title: Text with nautical terms and with link to external glossary for words used in unusual or restricted way
formalMetadata.dc:creator: Christophe.Strobbe@esat.kuleuven.be

recommendation.label: XHTML™ 1.0 The Extensible HyperText Markup Language (Second Edition)

purpose.p: This test case is intended to pass because there is a link to a glossary for the words that are used in an unusual or restricted way. However, browser support for the link element will determine if a user can access the glossary.

userGuidance.p: A text with nautical jargon is presented to you. Do not care about understanding the content of the text, because the only goal of this test is to evaluate whether the mechanism of presenting word definitions is adequate. Please read the first paragraph and look in the dictionary for definitions of the words “cruisers” and “destroyers” one after another. Then read the second paragraph and look in the dictionary for the definition of the word “turrets”.

questionText.p: Was the mechanism of presenting the word definitions adequate?

optionOther.p: Please provide your comments in regard to possible difficulties with the presentation mechanism. Suggestions on improvements are welcome as well:

functionalOutcome.p: The user can find definitions of technical terms.

techComment.p: Whether the user can find the link to the glossary (defined by the link element) really depends on the user agent. Mozilla 1.7.3 and Opera 7.54 support this type of links; Internet Explorer and Firefox 1.0 don't.
